item.title: Êå•ËàûÁùÄËùôËù†ÁöÑÁΩóÂàáÊñØÁâπÁî∑Â≠êÊèèËø∞‰∫Ü‰ªñÂú®Ë°óÂå∫‰∏ä‰∏éÂ±±ÁãÆÁöÑËøëË∑ùÁ¶ªÊé•Ëß¶Ôºö ‚ÄúÂÆÉËØ¥rawr ÔºÅ‚Äù | Bat- wielding Rochester man describes close encounter with mountain lion on his block: ‚ÄòIt said rawr!‚Äô
item.description:
This New Yorker is getting his dander up over a reported mountain lion roaming Rochester.

Curtis Jones said he has armed himself with a baseball bat after he spotted the big cat lurking around his block last week ‚Äî and locked eyes with the beast as it slinked by and sent neighbors scattering.

‚ÄúIt when right over there, and it said ‚ÄòRawr!'‚Äù said Jones, who spotted the panther prowling around his street Wednesday. ‚ÄúI seen it, see me, see it.‚Äù

‚ÄúI heard the ‚ÄòRawr,‚Äô I felt the ‚ÄòRawr.‚Äô I know he be pushing, I know that,‚Äù Jones told WHAM. ‚ÄúIn my head I‚Äôm like, ‚ÄòNo, I gotta go, man. I‚Äôm out.'‚Äù

He was just one of numerous people in the Rochester neighborhood who reported spotting the beast last Wednesday, prompting police to order a shelter in place while a search for the suspected cougar was launched.

Officials were unable to verify the sightings, so the order was lifted ‚Äî but witnesses like Jones say they know what they saw, and are keeping prepared to avoid becoming panther prey.

‚ÄúThey ain‚Äôt find it last night. It‚Äôs still out here, it could be out here in one of these bushes,‚Äù he said, pointing into nearby treetops. ‚ÄúYou know them mountain lions, it be ‚ÄòRawr,‚Äô they be crawling, you know. They serious.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt about like this big, it was just walking, slithering. I don‚Äôt know man,‚Äù Jones said. ‚ÄúImma keep this bat right here, man, just in case. I‚Äôm gonna protect this. I ain‚Äôt gonna let nothing happen to us, nothin‚Äô, okay?‚Äù

But Jones is hoping it doesn‚Äôt come to that.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt play with lions, I don‚Äôt play with tigers, bears, nothin‚Äô with the wild, I don‚Äôt play with those. I promise you.‚Äù Jones added, shaking his head.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt even do roller coasters. I‚Äôm good.‚Äù

Home security footage appeared to capture a ferocious feline stalking down a Rochester sidewalk Wednesday night, while the the Monroe County Sheriff‚Äôs Office deployed a drone to search the area.

Rochester‚Äôs Seneca Zoo even weighed in, assuring authorities that none of its animals had escaped.

Mountain lines haven‚Äôt had a sustained population in New York since the 1800s, according to the Department of Environmental Conservation (DEC), though they have been known to range through the state from as far away as South Dakota.

The last confirmed sighting of a cougar in New York was 2011, but the DEC says the animal in the doorcam footage does appear to be one.

‚ÄúDEC is actively investigating reports of a big cat in a Rochester neighborhood and determining if there is evidence to validate the images,‚Äù the DEC said in a statement.

‚ÄúAdditional information will be provided as it becomes available. DEC reminds the public to treat an encounter like any other with a large, potentially dangerous wild animal or unfamiliar dog.
item.author: Alex Oliveira

item.title: Ê≥ïÂÆòÂà§ÂÆöËá™1980Âπ¥‰ª•Êù•Âõ†ÂêëË≠¶ÂØüÊäïÊé∑ÊâãÊ¶¥ÂºπËÄåË¢´Âà§ÂÖ•Áã±ÁöÑÁ∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇÁî∑Â≠êÊúâÁΩ™‚ÄîÂõ†‰∏∫ÂÆÉ‰∏çÊòØÁàÜÁÇ∏ÊÄßÁöÑ | Judge tosses conviction of NYC man jailed since 1980 for hurling grenade at cops ‚Äî because it wasn‚Äôt explosive
item.description:
A Queens man who has spent more than 40 years in prison after hurling a hand grenade at cops was just cleared of the charges by a state appeals court ‚Äî because the device was a dud.

Supreme Court Judge Gia Morris ruled last week that Michael Bossett, 68 ‚Äî who was found guilty of five counts of attempted murder of a police officer in 1981 ‚Äî knew the projectile didn‚Äôt pack any explosives and therefore never intended to kill the cops, as prosecutors argued.

Now Bossett is set to go before a state parole board, where he has a chance of being freed.

He is behind bars for a murder on Long Island, too, but now that the grenade charge has been tossed, he‚Äôs facing a combined sentence of 37 1/2 years to life instead of 50 years to life ‚Äî and he‚Äôs served nearly 45 years already.

‚ÄúEven though it has taken almost 45 years for justice to prevail, Mr. Bossett never lost hope that his wrongful conviction would be overturned,‚Äù his lawyer, Ron Kuby, told The Post.

‚ÄúThe case is a remnant of the bad old days of policing, where cops and prosecutors would base cases on a ‚Äòif he didn‚Äôt do this, he did something else‚Äù philosophy that ruined the lives of so many innocent people,‚Äù Kuby added.

But the judge‚Äôs ruling Thursday doesn‚Äôt mean Bossett is out of the woods.

The accused onetime gangbanger still faces a murder conviction on Long Island ‚Äî and was linked to the shooting death of another of New York‚Äôs Finest just hours before the 1980 grenade fiasco.

Bossett‚Äôs brother, 69-year-old Darrell Bossett, is serving a life sentence for the cowardly 1980 shooting death of NYPD veteran Gabriel Vitale, 42, who died nine days after being gunned down while investigating a burglary in Queens.

Although Michael Bossett, who was with his brother at the time of the shooting, wasn‚Äôt convicted in the case, Vitale‚Äôs family still holds him equally accountable and calls the decision to throw out the attempted-murder grenade charges a fiasco.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs even worse that this criminal will now be unjustly eligible for parole,‚Äù said Cyndy Vitale, the slain cop‚Äôs daughter, to The Post in a statement. ‚ÄúI grew up with many line-of-duty families, bonding over our shared experience in losing a hero father.

‚ÄúNow so many of those killers are being set free to spend time with their families, while we were robbed of time with our fathers,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs appalling how the courts and parole system prioritize the rights of criminals over justice for the victims. It‚Äôs a complete moral failure.‚Äù

Cyndy Vitale and the NYPD Police Benevolent Association are also furious that Bossett‚Äôs key witness at the grenade hearing was a childhood friend ‚Äî and an ex-cop.

‚ÄúIt is absolutely shameful that the court would credit the far-fetched, self-serving tales being spun on the witness stand and ignore the simple fact that this drug-dealing murderer tried to kill New York City police officers,‚Äù PBA President Patrick Hendry said in a statement.

‚ÄúThis fight isn‚Äôt over,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre going to continue to stand with P.O. Vitale‚Äôs family to ensure that both of the individuals connected with his murder stay behind bars for life.‚Äù

Michael Bossett, then a reputed gang member, had his Queens apartment raided by cops Dec. 15, 1980.

According to court records, Bossett, who was 24 at the time, jumped out with a gun and hurled the hand grenade at the officers, who opened fire and wounded the career criminal.

In last week‚Äôs ruling, Morris said Bossett had previously thrown the inactive grenade at a friend and knew at the time of the incident with cops that it posed no danger.

Bossett still has drug and weapons-possession charges against him in the grenade incident and is serving a sentence of 25 years to life for a separate fatal shooting in Suffolk County.

In that case, he was convicted in February 1983 in the gang-related shooting death of Donald ‚ÄúRommel‚Äù McGirth, whose body was found handcuffed and tossed in the woods along a Long Island highway on Aug. 30, 1980 ‚Äî a few months before the grenade incident ‚Äî in what prosecutors described as a drug dispute.

A rep for the Queens District Attorney‚Äôs Office said the judge‚Äôs ruling in the grenade case only means Bossett is now facing a combined sentence of 37 1/2 years to life, instead of the 50 years to life he had been facing.

But Kuby maintained that his client has more than served his time.

‚ÄúHe has paid for that crime and would have been paroled 20 years ago, but for the wrongful conviction,‚Äù he said. ¬†
item.author: Jorge Fitz-Gibbon

item.title: Ê≤°ÊúâÂÖ¨ÁâõÔºÅËøô‰∫õÊòØÊúÄËøëÂú®Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇÊúÄÁñØÁãÇÁöÑÂºÇÂõΩÂä®Áâ©ÊïëÊè¥Ë°åÂä®ÔºåË∑ØÊòìÊñØÂÆâÈÇ£Â∑û | No bull! These are the wildest recent exotic-animal rescues in NYC, LI
item.description:
John Di Leonardo got a shocking call when a Long Island bull that famously escaped slaughter in 2023 was finally found after two months on the lam in Suffolk County.

‚ÄúWe were on the phone with the police. They said, ‚ÄòWe‚Äôre gonna shoot him,‚Äô ‚Äù Di Leonardo, Humane Long Island‚Äôs executive director and anthrozoologist, recently recalled to The Post.

‚ÄúI yelled, ‚ÄòNo, don‚Äôt do that! I‚Äôll get a sanctuary on the way! I‚Äôll be right there!‚Äô So thankfully, they listened and just corralled him and did not take that shot they had planned,‚Äù he said.

The frantic intervention landed the iconically brash bovine, aptly renamed ‚ÄúBully Joel‚Äù after another famous Long Islander, a peaceful life in New Jersey.

It also was just one of many wild encounters Di Leonardo has had on the job, where he strives to protect all creatures great and small from Manhattan to Montauk.

‚ÄúWe save about 1,200 animals a year,‚Äù Di Leonardo said on the grounds of Humane Long Island‚Äôs Baiting Hollow facility, where he and his wife, Juliana, care for animals before their new, safe forever home gets finalized.

‚ÄúWe get animals in every single week. It could be a handful ‚Äî or it could be 200,‚Äù said Di Leonardo, who has safely wrangled many other bulls in his job as well.

Di Leonardo‚Äôs role is treating critters that are either abandoned or rescued from harrowing circumstances across Long Island and parts of New York City, such as a small kangaroo ‚Äî also called a wallaby ‚Äî named ‚ÄúJackie Legs‚Äù who was recovered from the Coney Island boardwalk in 2023.

‚ÄúWe actually got a call about him being exploited in Madison Square Park. There was a guy charging money for pictures,‚Äù he said, recalling that a concerned citizen had no luck with police, as they were unfamiliar with legal technicalities.

Eventually, Di Leonardo teamed up with the NYPD‚Äôs animal cruelty unit to create an undercover operation, using the volunteer caller as a spy to tail the marsupial‚Äôs handler, then 22-year-old Michael Gibbons, who had bought his pet for nearly $4,000.

‚ÄúShe sat on him for a couple of hours while the authorities got themselves together, got down there and confiscated that wallaby,‚Äù Di Leonardo said. ‚ÄúNow he lives in a sanctuary where he‚Äôs living a much more natural life.‚Äù

Another time last year, the animal rescuer had the task of handling a South African ostrich, also known as a lesser rhea, found inside a Bellmore, LI, basement with several other exotic animals.

‚ÄúIt was huge at 5 months old ‚Äî almost as tall as me,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúShe was surrounded by venomous reptiles, and I‚Äôm sure she was terrified.‚Äù

Other cases involve animal abandonment, such as a recent baker‚Äôs dozen of ducks rescued from a Brookhaven, LI, park.

He said Suffolk County has become an unfortunate recent hotspot for abandoned animals, particularly since the Double D Bar Ranch in Manorville was slammed with 112 animal-neglect counts last winter.

‚ÄúWe had over 160 birds from them,‚Äù said Di Leonardo, who‚Äôs been swung at and gotten death threats while doing his job at times.

In other instances, he‚Äôs negotiated the release of animals from slaughterhouses by trading vegan food with the businesses.

Di Leonardo also released an extremely rare orange lobster into North Fork waters after it was spotted inside the tank of a ShopRite in Bay Shore on Friday. The grocery chain was happy to oblige.

Di Leonardo, who used to work with people with special needs, said, ‚ÄúI always wanted to help the group that needed the most in the world.

‚ÄúRight now, there‚Äôs no other group on the planet that is being exploited and harmed on such a large scale as animals.‚Äù

He said one of his favorite aspects of the job, where many rescues will be viewable at Humane Long Island‚Äôs Aug. 6 gala in Riverhead, is witnessing how animals adapt after just a few days out of harm‚Äôs way.

‚ÄúThey‚Äôve never known a human touch to be a good thing. So when they come, they‚Äôre often terrified,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúAfter a couple of days or maybe a couple of weeks, they realize that we‚Äôre here to love them and care for them. Many of them become very social and will follow us around and crave our attention.‚Äù
item.author: Alex Mitchell

item.title: ÂèÇËÆÆÂëòËØ¥ÔºåÁ∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇDemsÈÄöËøáÊîØÊåÅMamdani ‚ÄúÊãõÂãü‰∫∫Âëò‚ÄùÊê¨Âà∞‰ΩõÁΩóÈáåËææÂ∑ûÔºå ‚ÄúÁñØÁãÇ‚Äù | NYC Dems ‚Äòrecruiting people‚Äô to move to Florida by backing Mamdani, senator says: ‚ÄòInsanity‚Äô
item.description:
New York City pols backing socialist Zohran Mamdani for mayor are just ‚Äúrecruiting people to move to Florida,‚Äô‚Äô Sen. Rick Scott (R-Fla.) said Sunday ‚Äî calling the situation ‚Äúinsanity.‚Äô‚Äô

‚ÄúEvery elected official of New York on the Democratic side seems like they‚Äôre just recruiting people to move to Florida. It‚Äôs just insanity,‚Äù Scott said on WABC 770 AM‚Äôs ‚ÄúCats Roundtable‚Äù program.

‚ÄúAre you going to vote for somebody who wants to kill your job, ruin your kid‚Äôs education and then also make you less safe? That‚Äôs what they‚Äôre doing,‚Äù the senator told host John Catsimatidis.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt know what these Democrats think they are doing. Who do they represent?
‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not going to do that in Florida,‚Äù Scott said.

Florida politicians and business trade groups have been tripping over themselves to woo Big Apple CEOs and residents who are worried about the likelihood of Mamdani being elected mayor and pushing for tax hikes of up to $9 billion on the wealthy residents and corporations to pay for his agenda of more affordable housing, child care and free-bus fare fares.

Boca Raton Mayor Scott Singer, for one, is rolling out the red carpet and beaches, along with Palm Beach County economic development officials and Florida‚Äôs Council of 100 business leaders.

The Mamdani campaign did not respond to a Post request for comment.
item.author: Carl Campanile

item.title: ÊåÅÁâåÂè∏Êú∫Ë°®Á§∫ÔºåÁßªÊ∞ëËØàÈ™óËÄÖÊ≠£Âú®‚ÄúÂä´ÊåÅ‚ÄùÁ∫ΩÁ∫¶‰∏âËΩÆËΩ¶Ë°å‰∏ö | Migrant scammers are ‚Äòhijacking‚Äô NYC pedicab industry, licensed drivers say
item.description:
Licensed city pedicab drivers fume that a flood of migrants zooming around on rogue contraptions are the ones ripping off tourists and disrupting Broadway shows ‚Äî at their expense.

The angry pedalers claim their legit business has dropped by around 60% since the pandemic because of the illegal three-wheel scourges, who they said came to the Big Apple from places such as Turkey and Tajikistan during COVID.

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre hijacking our industry,‚Äù said New York Pedicab Alliance President and 16-year pedicab driver Makan Camara. ‚ÄúWhat we want is to make sure we have price options that fit our business so we can get [tourists‚Äô] trust back.‚Äù

The blow to business has gotten so bad that the New York Pedicab Alliance ‚Äì a group of more than 200 pedicab drivers that incorporated in December to help regulate and ‚Äúprotect‚Äù what they call a tourist attraction ‚Äì rallied on the steps of City Hall last week.

The group is demanding stricter enforcement of the rising ‚Äúcriminal culture.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre getting less business because of scammers,‚Äù said NYPA rep and 21-year driver Kenneth Winter. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs gotten a lot worse now.

‚ÄúThis became the new gold rush, and [the rogue drivers] take people for as much as possible. If we have no enforcement, they keep coming.¬†

‚ÄúI used to work four days a week, but now it‚Äôs up to six or seven [days], 8 to 12 hours a day,‚Äù added Winter, 55, who said he makes about $200 a day by charging a $35 flat per-ride fare.

Despite only about 850 pedicab licenses issued by the city, the NYPA estimates that nearly twice that figure ‚Äî or more than 1,500 of the three-wheeled vehicles ‚Äî cater to tourists in Midtown.

The group claims it has reported price-gougers ‚Äî who have been known to charge up to $1,000 per jaunt, use misleading signs and demand illegal ‚Äúper person‚Äù fees ‚Äî to Midtown NYPD precincts but that the cases are seldom ever prosecuted.

Predatory drivers have gotten so bold since 2020 that actors inside Broadway shows are even ad-libbing popular songs blasted by the rogue pedicabbies waiting to pounce on theatergoers outside, the NYPA said.

‚ÄúThe speakers are illegal already,‚Äù Winter said. ‚ÄúConfiscate them, especially if [their operators] don‚Äôt have a [pedicab] license.‚Äù

Winter said some tourists are getting scammed out of hundreds of dollars, also, including one victim who was charged $968 for a pedicab trip.¬†

The group also demanded the city legalize electric assist technology on pedicabs.

A longtime driver who goes by Frankie Legs told The Post that regularly pedaling a 700-pound passenger load without electric assist ‚Äúkilled me.

‚ÄúWe have guys who had to leave the industry and can‚Äôt do it anymore,‚Äù Winter said. ‚ÄúIt can have many health effects, biking so much ‚Äì some of us had to have knee replacements.‚Äù

At the Tuesday rally, the group also called for City Hall to regulate the sky-high price of insurance for pedicabs ‚Äì which is now up to $5,000 per bike and is offered by a single Florida-based agency.

‚ÄúIt was $700 per bike annually before pandemic,‚Äù Winter said.

An NYPD rep told The Post that 1,851 pedicab-related summonses have been issued and 165 illegal pedicabs seized in the confines of Midtown North and South so far this year.

‚ÄúThe NYPD continues to conduct enforcement on pedicabs on both the precinct level and through the Community Link Initiative, which addresses chronic quality of life conditions throughout New York City,‚Äù the representative said.

A rep from City Hall told The Post, ‚ÄúMayor Adams agrees that illegally operated pedicabs have no place on our streets ‚Ä¶ particularly in Central Park, where it has been a persistent issue.‚Äù

The representative said an ‚Äúeducational flyer‚Äù will be distributed throughout the park in the future to help tourists avoid rip-offs.

A new quality-of-life initiative ‚Äì including a fleet of 1,500 officers to manage noise, vending and unlicensed pedicabs in the park ‚Äî also debuted this spring, and a specialized task force is also working with Midtown Community Justice Center to identify and address repeat offenders, the mayor‚Äôs office said.
item.author: Nicole Rosenthal

item.title: ÊøÄËøõÁöÑÂ§ßÂ≠¶Âõ¢‰ΩìMamdaniËÅîÂêàÂàõÁ´ãÔºåÂ∏åÊúõ‰∏∫‰ªéÁæéÂõΩÈ©±ÈÄêÁöÑË¢´ÂÆöÁΩ™ÁöÑÊÅêÊÄñÂàÜÂ≠ê‰º∏Âº†Ê≠£‰πâ | Radical college group Mamdani co-founded wanted justice for convicted terrorist deported from US
item.description:
The Bowdoin College chapter of radical group Students for Justice in Palestine, co-founded by socialist NYC mayoral frontrunner Zohran Mamdani, went to bat for a terrorist convicted of deadly bombings in Israel ‚Äî and was then later booted out of the US for immigration fraud.

Rasmieh Yousef Odeh, 70, was convicted for a pair of bombings in Israel she helped execute in 1969 ‚Äî one at a Supersol supermarket that killed two college students and a second at the British Consulate in the country.

Odeh helped carry out the heinous crimes under the flag of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine (PFLP), a US-designated terror group.

The Palestinian-Jordanian radical was sentenced to life in prison in Israel after she was convicted in 1970, but was released in 1979 as part of a prisoner exchange.

Odeh then arrived in the US from Jordan on an immigrant visa in 1994 and became a citizen in 2004.

The terrorist was ordered deported in 2017 for lying about her involvement in the bombings on both her visa and US citizenship application.

Still, in 2014, the year Mamdani graduated from Bowdoin College, SJP shared an article about her case from The Hill on Facebook, and crowed, ‚ÄúJustice for Rasmea Odeh!‚Äù

A Facebook account linked to Mamdani also ‚Äúliked‚Äù the statement, which was viewed by The Post.

The upstart socialist helped launch the Bowdoin chapter of SJP during his time at the elite college.

The same group in 2013 also invited radical Lebanese-American speaker, As‚Äôad AbuKhalil, to address the student body.

AbuKhalil has sensationally called Israel a bigger terror threat than Iran and boasted he was greatly influenced by a Palestinian leader with the nickname the ‚Äúgodfather of Middle Eastern terrorism.‚Äù

Independent New York City mayoral candidate Jim Walden hit out at Mamdani on X for SJP‚Äôs social media post in support of Odeh, saying it ‚Äúpraised her as a victim‚Äù and calling it ‚Äúradical extremism and antisemitism.‚Äù

Remi Kanazi, an author and poet affiliated with SJP, also tweeted his support of Odeh in a 2014 post on X, writing, ‚ÄúWhy is the Obama administration prosecuting torture victim Rasmea Odeh? Drop the charges: Write or call in TODAY,‚Äù he wrote with a link to an endtheoccupation.org article that has since been taken offline.

In her 2017 plea agreement, Odeh admitted lying about her criminal history and convictions in her US immigration applications, and that she knew it was against the law to provide false information to the US government.

‚ÄúHad Odeh revealed the truth about her criminal history, as she was required to by law, she never would have been granted an immigrant visa, admitted to the United States, allowed to live here for the last 22 years or granted United States citizenship,‚Äù the plea read.

She was stripped of her citizenship, barred from the country for life and deported to Jordan.

Though Mamdani graduated from Bowdoin in spring 2014, the¬†SJP chapter he founded has continued to engage in increasingly radical activism.

Earlier this year, the group occupied a campus building as part of a protest against the school‚Äôs investment practices and President Trump hinting at taking control of war-torn Gaza, the Bowdoin Orient wrote.

Meanwhile, Mamdani himself has raised eyebrows with several past statements and social media posts that appeared to be sympathetic to known terrorists.

In one resurfaced tweet, Mamdani appeared to defend al Qaeda menace Anwar al-Awalaki, who was later taken out in a drone strike approved by then-President Barack Obama.

In his days as a rapper, Mamdani praised the heads of the so-called ‚ÄúHoly Land Five,‚Äù the Holy Land Foundation for Relief and Development, an infamous nonprofit convicted of funneling more than $12 million to the terror group Hamas.

Mamdani‚Äôs camp did not immediately respond to The Post‚Äôs request for comment.
item.author: Carl Campanile, Chris Nesi

item.title: ÁÉ≠Áà±È©¨ÂßÜËææÂ∞ºÁöÑÂ∏ÉÊãâÂæ∑¬∑ÂÖ∞Âæ∑Ôºà Brad Lander ÔºâÈÄöËøá‚ÄúÊí§Âõû‚ÄùÂÄ∫Âà∏Êù•ÊäµÂà∂ÂèçÂØπ‰ª•Ëâ≤ÂàóÁöÑËøêÂä®Ôºö‰∫öÂΩìÊñØÈòµËê• | Mamdani-loving Brad Lander aids boycott movement against Israel with ‚Äòwithdrawal‚Äô of bonds: Adams‚Äô camp
item.description:
City Comptroller and Zohran Mamdani crony Brad Lander has aided boycott efforts against Israel by withdrawing union pension funds from bonds issued by the Jewish state, Mayor Eric Adams‚Äô top deputy claims.

‚ÄúI write on behalf of the Adams Administration to request a review of the decision-making process surrounding the effective withdrawal of New York City pensions funds from investment in State of Israel Bonds,‚Äù First Deputy Mayor Randy Mastro said in a July 10 letter to Lander and obtained by The Post.

‚ÄúThis divestment, occurring amid a global Boycott, Divestment, and Sanctions (BDS) campaign against Israel, appears to be in furtherance of that BDS campaign, regardless of the adverse financial consequences for city pensioners,‚Äù Mastro wrote to Lander, who is in charge of overseeing the city‚Äôs finances, including its pension investments.

‚ÄúYour public characterization of this shift as a mere ‚Äúdecision not to reinvest‚Äô does not insulate it from scrutiny.‚Äù

The Big Apple first invested $30 million in State of Israel Bonds in 1974 under former city Comptroller Harrison Goldin through its pension funds for educators.

Over the years, successive city Comptrollers Elizabeth Holtzman, Alan Hevesi, Bill Thompson, John Liu and Scott Stringer have all reinvested the bonds as they matured.

But now only the city Police Pension Fund has a little more than $1 million invested in Israel Bonds.

By comparison, the New York state pension system, run by state Comptroller Tom DiNapoli, has more than $360 million invested in the Jewish state.

‚ÄúWe request a review because the public record is incomplete as to the basis for and impact of your decision to withdrawal [of] investment in Israel Bonds,‚Äù Mastro said in his letter. ‚ÄúIt appears, based on available information, that the city‚Äôs pension systems had held tens of millions of dollars in State of Israel Bonds across multiple decades, with a record of strong returns and minimal risk.

‚ÄúUnder your tenure, those holdings have declined sharply, from tens of millions of dollars across multiple pension funds, to now less than $1.2 million held only by the Police Pension Fund,‚Äù Mastro said.

‚ÄúThis reduction appears to be the result of a sustained and coordinated decision on your part not to reinvest in State of Israel Bonds upon maturity. Moreover, this decision has adversely affected the performance of the pension funds‚Äô bond portfolios because State of Israel bonds have outperformed other bonds in which the pension funds are invested,‚Äù the Adams‚Äô deputy said in the letter.

Israel bonds are considered a solid investment, accumulating about 5% returns on average a year, records show.

It‚Äôs unclear how much the workers‚Äô pension funds may have lost by the city comptroller‚Äôs move.

Lander and Israel-bashing socialist buddy Mamdani cross-endorsed each other in the city‚Äôs Democratic primary in June ‚Äî a move that is credited with helping propel the far-left Mamdani well in front of the pack to clinch the party‚Äôs nomination.

‚ÄúYou have publicly stated that your decision was based on limiting investment in foreign sovereign debt, not to divest Israel Bonds,‚Äù Mastro said in his letter to Lander. ‚ÄúBut it appears that the only sovereign bonds in which the city has invested are Israel Bonds, so this policy appears to target only Israel Bonds.

‚ÄúYou have a fiduciary duty to the city‚Äôs pensioners that is now called into question by your decision in this regard.‚Äù

The comptroller‚Äôs office oversees the city‚Äôs five pension systems: the Teachers‚Äô Retirement System of the City of New York; the New York City Employees‚Äô Retirement System; the New York City Police Pension Fund; the New York City Fire Pension Fund; and the Board of Education Retirement System of the City of New York.

The mayor also has a representative on each of the pension boards along with the comptroller and union reps.

Mastro requested that Lander‚Äôs office provide copies of all documents and communications relating to the decision whether to purchase Israel Bonds after the existing one mature. Those communications would include discussions with outside parties, the Adams aide said. He requested a response by July 17.

Adams, a Democrat, is running for re-election as an independent and is seeking support from Jewish constituents. He faces off against Democratic nominee Zohran Mamdani, Republican nominee Curtis Sliwa, ex-Gov. Andrew Cuomo and lawyer Jim Walden, the latter two who are also both running on independent ballot lines.

Mamdani is an outspoken supporter of the BDS movement against Israel.

Lander‚Äôs office had no comment to The Post, but he was forced to address the issue during his unsuccessful Democratic primary campaign for mayor.

The comptroller, who is Jewish, said he opposes the BDS movement against Israel.

‚ÄúLander has never divested,‚Äù a rep for the comptroller said in March. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a policy of his office to never invest in foreign sovereign debt, but we have more than $400 million in investments in Israeli companies.‚Äù
item.author: Carl Campanile

item.title: ÂâçÂ∑ûÈïøÂ§ßÂç´¬∑Â∏ïÁâπÊ£ÆÔºà David Paterson ÔºâËØ¥ÔºåÁãÇÁÉ≠ÁöÑÈ©¨ÂßÜËææÂ∞ºÔºà Mamdani ÔºâÊîØÊåÅËÄÖÂú®ÂÖ¨ÂºÄÂèçÂØπÁ§æ‰ºö‰∏ª‰πâËÄÖÂêéÁûÑÂáÜ‰∫Ü‰ªñÁöÑÂÆ∂‰∫∫Ôºö ‚ÄúÂ∞ñÂàª‚Äù | Ex-Gov. David Paterson said rabid Mamdani supporters targeted his family after he spoke out against socialist: ‚Äòvitriolic‚Äô
item.description:
Former New York Gov. David Paterson said his family was flooded with ‚Äúvitriolic‚Äù calls from rabid Zohran Mamdani supporters after he suggested Eric Adams or Andrew Cuomo should drop out of the mayoral race ‚Äî to block the socialist from winning.

‚ÄúI got a whole lot of nasty, negative phone calls ‚Äî really vitriolic ‚Äî from Mamdani supporters,‚Äù Paterson said on John Catsimatidis‚Äô ‚ÄúCat‚Äôs Rountable‚Äù on WABC 770 AM.

‚Äú[They] called my home. They called my wife. It was really kind of difficult for those 48 hours after the press conference.‚Äù

Unfazed, Paterson doubled down on his call to block Mamdani, who won the Democratic mayoral primary in a shocking upset, from City Hall.

‚ÄúIf Andrew Cuomo and Eric Adams both stay in the mayor‚Äôs race, it will be [an] open door for Zohran Mamdani to win the election in November for mayor,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúMy proposal was that there be a way to make a decision [on] which of these two candidates should run against Mamdani.‚Äù

Cuomo, meanwhile, is expected to announce this week that he is¬†staying in the race¬†as an independent, sources told NewsNation.

Mamdani, a state assemblyman from Queens, defeated Cuomo in the Democratic primary for the mayor‚Äôs seat.

Mayor Adams is also still vying to return to office, running as an independent.

Guardian Angels founder Curtis Sliwa is running on the Republican line.

The victory by Mamdani, a Muslim born in Uganda, shook up the Big Apple political establishment.

‚ÄúThe reason I have such a problem with Mr. Mamdani is because, in the beginning, he was a young candidate,‚Äù the former governor told Catsimatidis. ‚ÄúHad new ideas, Very charismatic. Can make a crowd really cheer for him.

‚ÄúBut he has never evidenced a plan for changing pretty much anything in the city,‚Äù Paterson said.

He cited Mamdani‚Äôs comments after George Floyd was killed during a 2020 confrontation with police in Minneapolis, which sparked tensions and protests throughout the nation.

‚ÄúHe said things like, ‚ÄòWell, it‚Äôs too bad it had to happen, but it had to happen,'‚Äù Paterson recalled. ‚ÄúWhy did it have to happen? This is not the way we make change in this country ‚Äî by rioting.‚Äù

He said the best path to blocking a Mamdani mayoralty is for Adams or Cuomo to step aside.

‚ÄúIf they both don‚Äôt get out of the race and Mamdani wins, I think they‚Äôre going to draw a lot of criticism,‚Äù Paterson said. ‚ÄúThe responsibility of these two candidates is to either get out or not get out.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think that it‚Äôs fair to order anyone to get out of the a race, but I think it‚Äôs fair to tell the, ‚ÄòWhat‚Äôs going to happen if they stay in?‚Äù
item.author: Jorge Fitz-Gibbon

item.title: ÂÆâÂæ∑È≤Å¬∑ÁßëËé´Ôºà Andrew Cuomo ÔºâÂ∞Ü‰Ωú‰∏∫Áã¨Á´ã‰∫∫Â£´ÂèÇÂä†Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇÈïøÁ´ûÈÄâ‚Äî‰ΩÜÊúâ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÈóÆÈ¢ò | Andrew Cuomo set to run as an independent in NYC mayoral race ‚Äî but there‚Äôs a catch
item.description:
Not Cuoing anywhere.

Andrew Cuomo is expected to announce this week that he is staying in the New York mayoral race as an independent, despite the latest polls showing his odds of winning are slim.

The former governor is going to unveil his independent candidate bid this week, sources told NewsNation ‚Äî but there is a catch.

After his announcement, Cuomo is going to ask all of the candidates ‚Äî except for socialist Democratic nominee Zohran Mamdani ‚Äî to vow to drop out of the race come mid-September if they are not in the lead, himself included, a source close to the candidate told NewsNation.

The Post has reached out to Cuomo‚Äôs campaign for comment.

The decision comes despite polls showing the former governor trailing Mamdani.

The latest survey from from political consulting firm Slingshot Strategies has Mamdani comfortable leading with 35% of the vote, followed by Cuomo on 25%, Republican Curtis Sliwa in third with 14%, and Eric Adams in fourth with a paltry 11%.
item.author: Anthony Blair

item.title: Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇË≠¶ÊñπËøΩÊçïÊúüÈó¥ÔºåÁîµÂä®Ëá™Ë°åËΩ¶‰∏äÁöÑÊåÅÂàÄÊä¢Âä´Â´åÁñë‰∫∫Ë¢´Ê±ΩËΩ¶ÊíûÊ≠ª | Knife-wielding robbery suspect on e-bike hit and killed by car during NYC police chase
item.description:
A knife-wielding robbery suspect was killed after being struck by a car while fleeing police on an e-bike during a wild chase that began in Queens and ended in Long Island, police said.

Cops responded to 256-17 Hillside Avenue around 8:01 p.m. after receiving reports of an armed robbery, prompting the suspect to take off on the motorized bicycle, according to police.

The pursuit came to an end at Lakeview Road and Bryant Avenue in Nassau County, where the alleged perp was hit by a Lexus and suffered severe bodily trauma.

He was pronounced dead at the scene, cops said.

Police have not released the suspect‚Äôs name or age.

Grisly photos from the scene showed the man‚Äôs bloodied body covered by a white sheet as the NYPD and Nassau County conduct a joint investigation.

The investigation remains ongoing.
item.author: Anna Young

item.title: Â£∞Ê≥¢ÁßëÂ≠¶ÂÆ∂Âú®Â∏ÉÈ≤ÅÂÖãÊûóÁî®Âñ∑Â∞ÑÁÅ´ÁÑ∞ÁöÑÂÆûÈ™å‰ª™Âô®Âà∂‰ΩúÁÅ´ÁÑ∞Ë°®Êºî | Sonic scientists create fiery show in Brooklyn with experimental instruments that spew flames
item.description:
Shooting off pyrotechnics at a concert may be nothing new, but a music event where the instruments belch fire is certainly unique.

Fire the Band performed both Friday and Saturday night at Brooklyn‚Äôs Chocolate Factory, a warehouse space on Scott Avenue in East Williamsburg as part of their Mechasonic Sessions.

Dozens of artists came together for these sonic experimental collaborations, producing a storm of sound, pulsating light, and yes, fire.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs basically to give musicians and artists a way to do things that they couldn‚Äôt do in any other environment,‚Äù explained Stefan Zeniuk, Fire The Band‚Äôs musical director. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs for artist and musicians, by artists and musicians to do things they couldn‚Äôt do in other shows or environments.‚Äù

The event, the fourth of its kind, was organized for ‚Äúexploring how much further musical experiences can [go] for the audience,‚Äù Zenuik added, ‚Äúbut also for the performers and for people that are maybe not professional musicians, but are incredible thinkers and dreamers. And so we have endless ideas and text threads that just spiral into wild concepts.

‚ÄúWe keep trying to explore new ways that they can happen, you know? Lots of new noises. We like to come up with lots of new noises.‚Äù

Horn player Chris Cortier‚Äôs trombone shoots fire thanks to a propane system.

The last event was staged two years ago, and attracted 600 people ‚Äî and the FDNY.

Boasted Zeniuk:¬†‚ÄúZero injuries to date.‚Äù
item.author: Chris Harris, Aristide Economopoulos

item.title: Êé®ÂÄíÁãóÂ±ãÔºöÂèØÁà±ÁöÑÂÆ†Áâ©Âú®Ëàí‰ºØÁâπÂ∑∑‰∏éÊòéÊòüËÅö‰ºöÔºåÂèÇÂä†ÁôæËÄÅÊ±áBarksÈ¢ÜÂÖªÊ¥ªÂä® | Bringing down the dog house: cute pets gather with stars at Shubert Alley for Broadway Barks adoption event
item.description:
The star-studded 27th annual Broadway Barks dog and cat adoption event went off without a hitch Saturday at Shubert Alley, the heart of the Great White Way.

Broadway legend Bernadette Peters co-hosted the event with Beth Leavel, who just wrapped up an extended run in Stephen Sondheim‚Äôs ‚ÄúOld Friends.‚Äù

The presenters for this year‚Äôs event included three-time Tony Award winning actor Andy Karl, ‚ÄúMary Poppins‚Äù star Gavin Lee, ‚ÄúHell‚Äôs Kitchen‚Äù lead Jessica Vosk, and South African-born country singer and actor Orville Peck

Erika Henningsen from ‚ÄúMean Girls,‚Äù Lesli Margherita from ‚ÄúGypsy,‚Äù Erich Bergen from ‚ÄúJersey Boys,‚Äù and Michelle Williams from Destiny‚Äôs Child and ‚ÄúDeath Becomes Her‚Äù also served as presenters.

The event brings animal shelters and rescues from across New York into one spot, in hopes of finding forever homes for hundreds of loving pets.

The event is produced by Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS, and helps promote the importance of spaying and neutering throughout the Five Boroughs.
item.author: Chris Harris

item.title: Á§æ‰ºö‰∏ª‰πâÁ∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇÂ∏ÇÈïøÂÄôÈÄâ‰∫∫‰ΩêËµ´ÂÖ∞¬∑È©¨ÂßÜËææÂ∞ºÔºà Zohran Mamdani ÔºâÁöÑÁà∂‰∫≤ÊòØÂèç‰ª•Ëâ≤ÂàóÁªÑÁªáÂßîÂëò‰ºöÊàêÂëòÔºåÂêåÊÉÖËá™ÊùÄÂºèÁÇ∏ÂºπË¢≠ÂáªËÄÖ | Socialist NYC mayoral candidate Zohran Mamdani‚Äôs dad sits on council of anti-Israel group, sympathetic of suicide bombers
item.description:
The father of socialist NYC mayoral candidate Zohran Mamdani sits on an advisory council of an Israel-hating organization that routinely accuses the Jewish state of committing ‚Äúgenocide‚Äù ‚Äì and has expressed sympathy for suicide bombers.

Mahmood Mamdani, 79, is listed as one of 29 members of the London-based Gaza Tribunal‚Äôs advisory policy council.

The group, founded last year, says its primary goal is ‚Äúto awaken civil society to its responsibility and opportunity to stop Israel‚Äôs genocide in Gaza.‚Äù

It also supports many of the same anti-Israel causes being pushed by the Queens assemblyman and mayoral frontrunner, including the BDS movement, which urges¬†‚Äúboycott,¬†divestment¬†and sanctions‚Äù against¬†Israel¬†to push Palestinian causes.

The news that the elder Mamdani, a chaired professor of African history and colonialism at Columbia University, is part of the Gaza Tribunal was first reported Saturday by Fox News.

He has also come under fire on social media this week over a resurfaced book excerpt, in which he expressed sympathy for the way suicide bombers are viewed.

‚ÄúSuicide bombing needs to be understood as a feature of modern political violence rather than stigmatized as a mark of barbarism,‚Äù the elder Mamdani wrote in his 2004 book ‚ÄúGood Muslim, Bad Muslim: America, the Cold War, and the Roots of Terror.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe need to recognize the suicide bomber, first and foremost, as a category of soldier,‚Äù he also wrote.

‚ÄúThe apple @ZohranKMamdani doesn‚Äôt fall far from the tree,‚Äù quipped billionaire hedge fund titan¬†Bill Ackman on X Thursday.

Mahmood Mamdani could not immediately be reached for comment.
item.author: Rich Calder

item.title: Â∏ÉÈ≤ÅÂÖãÊûóÊπæÂ≤≠Ôºà Bay Ridge ÔºâÂ§ßÊ•ºÁáÉÁÉßÁùÄÂú∞Áã±Ëà¨ÁöÑÁúºÊ≥™ÔºåÂåÖÊã¨Ê∂àÈò≤ÂëòÂú®ÂÜÖÁöÑ4‰∫∫Âèó‰º§ | Blazing inferno tears through Bay Ridge building in Brooklyn, injuring 4 including firefighter
item.description:
Four people were hurt when a fast-burning blaze ripped through a Brooklyn apartment building Saturday, officials said.

The fire broke out on the top floor of the four-story building on Cropsey Ave., between Bay Parkway and Bay 31st Street in Bay Ridge around 11 a.m., fire officials said.¬†

A firefighter was taken to Coney Island Hospital in stable condition and three civilians were taken to NYU Langone Hospital with minor injuries, the FDNY said.

The firefighter was later released from the hospital, an FDNY spokesman said.¬†

Twelve FDNY units and 60 firefighters and EMS personnel responded to the smoky scene. The fire was under control by 12:15 p.m.

The FDNY Fire Marshals are investigating the cause of the flames.
item.author: Georgia Worrell, Tina Moore

item.title: Âú®‰∏§ÂêçÁî∑Â≠êÂú®‰∏çÂêåÁöÑ‰∫ã‰ª∂‰∏≠Ë∑≥ÂÖ•Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Ê∞¥ÂüüÂêéÔºåËá≥Â∞ëÊúâ‰∏Ä‰∫∫Ê≠ª‰∫° | At least one killed after two men jump into NYC waters in separate incidents
item.description:
Two men leapt into the waters of NYC, and at least one was killed, in separate incidents Saturday.

The first man plummeted from the Williamsburg Bridge into the East River around 8:30 a.m., a police spokesman said.

The man, whose name and age were unknown, was pulled from the water by the FDNY and brought to New York Presbyterian Hospital in critical condition but could not be saved, authorities said.

Witnesses saw a second man, whose name and age were also unknown, fully clothed and wearing a backpack jumping into the river from a Randall‚Äôs Island ferry landing at around 12:20 p.m., cops said.¬†

NYPD aviation and scuba units scoured the water searching for the man, but he was not immediately recovered, authorities said.
item.author: Tina Moore, Larry Celona

item.title: ËßÜÈ¢ë‰ºº‰πéÊòæÁ§∫Ôºå‰∏ÄÂêçÂ¶áÂ•≥Âú®Êñ∞Ê≥ΩË•øÂ∑ûÁöÑÂÜ∞‰∏äÊäóËÆÆËÄÖ‰∏≠ÁäÅÂú∞ÔºåÈÄ†Êàê3‰∫∫Âèó‰º§ | Video appears to show woman plowing through ICE protestors in New Jersey, injuring 3
item.description:
Video shared on social media appears to have captured the moment a woman in a gray Jeep appears to drive through protestors in North Bergen, New Jersey.

The incident unfolded outside Noches De Columbia on Fairview Avenue in Fairview where marchers, organized by a group called united Without Fear, were protesting ICE raids.

The footage shows the woman driving up to the restaurant‚Äôs exit, as a line of protestors streams slowly in front of her.

A protestor approaches the Jeep, to ensure the female driver will stop. He then turns from the vehicle, which lunges forward, clipping his foot.

The man falls near the car, and several protestors crowd around the Jeep.

The driver rolls up her window, and proceeds through the protestors.

Three people are said to have sustained minor injuries, including one victim who sustained an injury to their knee.

No arrests have been made as the driver is yet to be identified.

This is a developing story. Check back later for more details.
item.author: Chris Harris

item.title: Ëøô‰∫õÊòØËøáÂéªÂçÅÂπ¥Êàê‰∏∫ÊàøÂú∞‰∫ßÁÉ≠ÁÇπÁöÑË¢´ÈÅóÂøòÁöÑÁ∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇÔºöÊä•Âëä | These are the forgotten NYC nabes that became real estate hot spots in the last decade: report
item.description:
Dozens of forgotten NYC neighborhoods have become real estate hot spots, with home prices doubling ‚Äî or more ‚Äî over the past decade, a new report revealed.

Two Bridges, nestled between the Brooklyn and Manhattan bridges, saw the biggest price boom, with median home sales skyrocketing 288% from $423,000 in 2014 to more than $1.6 million in 2024, according to PropertyShark.

The whopping growth is from high-end real estate developments like One Manhattan Square, a waterfront skyscraper at 225 Cherry St. where a penthouse rents for a mind-boggling $45,000 per month, according to the report‚Äôs author, Eliza Theiss.

‚ÄúMajor high-end projects like this rapidly transformed the area,‚Äù Theiss told The Post. ‚ÄúCommunity resistance was overwhelmed by luxury expansion.‚Äù

Neighborhoods with the next steepest price climbs are on peninsulas ‚Äî including Queens‚Äô Breezy Point and Hamilton Beach, and Brooklyn‚Äôs Red Hook and Gerritsen Beach.

Breezy Point, an enclave which sits on the western end of the Rockaway peninsula, saw median sale prices grow 192% in the last decade, from $248,000 in 2014 to $725,000 in 2024.

Hamilton Beach, on a strip of land north of Jamaica Bay, saw prices surge 172% from $170,000 in 2014 to $462,000 in 2024.

These waterfront areas took a hit when Hurricane Sandy landed in 2012, wreaking havoc on real estate and environmental protection infrastructure, according to Theiss.

But the implementation of flood mitigation and other environmental protection measures in the areas saw wealthy real estate investors notice the opportunity, and they swooped in, she said.

‚ÄúDisaster recovery efforts raised the neighborhoods‚Äô safety and appeal,‚Äù she explained.

And when the pandemic hit in 2020, the shift to remote work trends opened up the demand for less transit-accessible, waterfront areas, Theiss noted.

Red Hook, a southern Brooklyn community that reaches into the Upper New York Bay, also saw a 150% increase in its median home sale prices, from $790,000 10 years ago to an eye-popping $1.975 million last year.

Gentrification played a factor in Red Hook‚Äôs booming popularity, said Theiss, as well as that of Gerritsen Beach, located on a sliver of land between Gerritsen and Shell Bank creeks, where the median home sale price climbed 136%, up to $520,000 from $220,000 a decade ago.

And in Gerritsen Beach‚Äôs case, its neighbors ‚Äì the popular Marine Park and Sheepshead Bay areas ‚Äì helped to funnel interest in the coastal nabe, as a result of what Theiss called ‚Äúa spillover effect.‚Äù

The impact is ‚Äúincreasingly polarizing,‚Äù she noted, adding ‚Äúaffordability is quickly vanishing.‚Äù

On the other hand, seven Big Apple neighborhoods ‚Äì six of them in Manhattan ‚Äì saw median home sale prices dip over the same timeframe.

Tudor City, an apartment complex that consumes the area between East 40th and 43rd streets and First and Second avenues, took the greatest hit, with prices falling 17% from $402,000 in 2014 to $335,000 last year.

Historical preservation restrictions, relatively small space offerings and its seclusion from the rest of Manhattan are just a few reasons why Tudor City‚Äôs popularity among investors have plummeted, Theiss noted.¬†

Median sale prices in the ritzy SoHo have shrunk 6% since 2014, from $3.4 million to $3.2 million and, in Flatiron, they‚Äôve decreased 6% from $1.54 million to $1.48 million. Condos in the posh areas cost more in 2024 than they did in 2014, while co-ops grew less expensive over the same period.
item.author: Georgia Worrell

item.title: 21Â≤ÅÁöÑÊñØÊ≤ÉË•øËµ¢Âæó‰∫Ü‚ÄúÂÆåÂÖ®ÂºÄÁé©Á¨ë‚ÄùÁöÑËé±ÊòÇÁ∫≥Â§ö¬∑Ëø™Âç°ÊôÆÈáåÂ••Ôºà Leonardo DiCaprio ÔºâÁõ∏‰ººÊØîËµõ | Swarthy 21-year-old wins ‚Äòcomplete joke‚Äô Leonardo DiCaprio lookalike contest
item.description:
He‚Äôs been crowned Dicaprio‚Äôs doppelg√§nger.

It was Leos galore in New Jersey on Saturday as lookalikes for a DiCaprio lookalike contest battled it out on stage for a $50 cash prize.

Among the seven contestants from places like Philadelphia and Providence was Nick Fine, 21, who was eventually crowned the winner. The swarthy local confessed to The Post he was thrilled to be likened to the handsome Academy Award-winning heartthrob.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs an absolute honor. I‚Äôm just very grateful I came to the pier this morning. I‚Äôm a big Leo fan, love his movies,‚Äù smiled Fine, who went on to name ‚ÄúShutter Island‚Äù as his favorite DiCaprio flick.

The contest, which took place at Pier A Park in Hoboken and drew in a crowd of 40, was organized by a group of college friends.

Hoboken resident Colleen Flickinger, who works as a public relations specialist, concocted the idea to celebrate her pal Margaret Pfeifle‚Äôs 25th birthday ‚Äî a play on the fact that DiCaprio, 50, has a habit of dumping his girlfriends once they turn 25.

‚ÄúLeonardo DiCaprio never dated anyone above 25, so for many, many years, that was the joke, so, when Margaret was turning 25, we just kind of were inspired by that, and we were like, ‚ÄòHow funny would it be if we had a look alike contest?'‚Äù Flickinger, also 25, explained.

‚ÄúIt was a complete joke. I printed out maybe 10 fliers, and then we posted it [on social media] and that‚Äôs when it kind of took off.‚Äù

‚ÄúHopefully it‚Äôs good for a laugh if nothing else,‚Äù Pfeifle, the birthday girl, added.

When only one contestant ‚Äî who had seen it advertised on social media ‚Äî showed up, the girls started recruiting potential contestants in the park.

They ended up finding five Leo lookalikes. [The seventh contestant, who had also learned about it on social media, arrived later.]

‚ÄúI‚Äôm kind of shocked how many people that look like Leonardo DiCaprio are walking around the park.‚Äù Flickinger said.

As fate would have it, Fine, who incidentally lives across from the park, happened to be strolling by with his friends.

‚ÄúActually a friend of mine was recruited, and then I got looped into it, and they said that they would cheer for me, so it all worked out, I guess. It is amazing,‚Äù he gushed.

‚ÄúI was just eating breakfast like two seconds ago, I came out to the pier for a second.‚Äù

Joining him in the competition were Michael Stewart, 47, a local retired iron worker, David Flanigan, 26, an underwriter from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, John Santos, 22, a jack-of-all trades from Providence, Rhode Island, and Eric Stylianidis, 22, a consultant who resides in the Big Apple.

Each contestant was asked to introduce themselves and were judged by the amount of applause they received.

When it was Fine‚Äôs turn, he simply stated, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm Nick, I live across the street. Leo is an absolute man rocket.‚Äù

After the first round, it came down to two contestants, Fine and Flanigan.

Then the crowd was asked to applaud again, and Fine was awarded the honor.

Soon after he was named the victor, he revealed what he‚Äôd be doing with his $50 winnings.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm gonna go get a few beers, probably within the next 30 minutes,‚Äù he said.
item.author: Angela Barbuti, Khristina Narizhnaya
